messages.subject: Fw: Anybody in Oz know what kind of sword?
messages.msgSnippet: David and All, Your link is one of the few that doesn t senationalise the attack, simply reporting a sword as being used.  Just about everthing else in print
messages.messageBody:
David and All,

Your link is one of the few that doesn't senationalise the attack, simply
reporting a "sword" as being used. Just about everthing else in print and
electronic media reported "samurai sword". See for example:

http://abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200511/s1495995.htm
http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/doubt-over-charges-after-burglar-killed-w
ith-sword/2005/11/02/1130823281025.html

Within a couple of days there was another "samurai sword" attack on the other
side of Melbourne:
http://www.news.com.au/story/0,10117,17146188-29277,00.html

Here is a bulletin board thread discussing a case in the UK that may be of
interest, seeing this issue appears to be well on the way to becoming a
world-wide phenomenon:
http://timlambert.org/2004/03/gullible/

From the few photos I've seen of the incident David Zincavage refers to the
sword looks like a repro of some sort - it's gunto-like but the tsuba is just
too brilliantly gold for it to be a real one. In a couple of months or so I'll
be retired and I intend to follow up on these with the police to identify all
the swords involved in "samurai sword" attacks here in Victoria leading up to
the infamous, ignorant and outrageous laws that we are well aware of. John's
email (excelsiorilluminati@...) spoke of:

> These attacks on people with 'Samurai Swords' are
> the exact reason there has been legislation enacted
> already with more being contemplated in certain parts
> of the world.

More information please. I think my home state of Victoria here in Oz was the
first in the West to introduce laws as a direct result of "samurai sword"
attacks, and we have heard of the Scottish move. Anything else?? Any more
details?? Perhaps it might be better to reply to me offline in this
"developmental" stage?? We can take the list's time and bandwidth in the event
of concrete actions by legislators. OR - keep the discussion online until
someone complains?? Personally I'm 'red-hot' on somehow correcting the
ignorance of our legislature here in Victoria as well as the media. Not sure
how I'll go about a one-man, retired old geezer moral minority campaign gainst
abysmal ignorance, but once retired I'll have 'the rest of my life' to get into
it...

Best regards,

Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)

----- Original Message -----
From: "David Zincavage" <jdz@...>
To: <token_kenkyu_kai@...>; <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, November 05, 2005 6:30 AM
Subject: Anybody in Oz know what kind of sword?


http://www.news.com.au/story/0,10117,17114699-421,00.html
